newsitem.title: USA: AT&T consumer traffic growth quickened in Q3.
newsitem.headline: AT&T consumer traffic growth quickened in Q3.

text.p: AT&T Corp, reporting a 12 percent drop in share profits, said on Thursday volume growth in its consumer telephony business picked up in the third quarter over the second.

"While competitive pressure continues in the consumer business, volume growth shows improvement over the previous quarter, particularly in international," the company said in its third quarter earnings report.
The company also said wireless services revenue, which include cellular, messaging and air-to-ground, grew 17.7 percent from a year before to $892 million in the quarter.
Consolidated cellular service subscribers grew to 4.78 million, a 33.3 percent increase from a year ago.
Wireline services revenue increased slightly more than two percent to $11.552 billion from last year's third quarter. The growth in long distance revenues came primarily from U.S. business services.
Long distance calling volumes grew slightly more than five percent over the same period in 1995.
Other communications revenues from such services as consulting and online, were $388 million, an increase of nearly 39 percent compared with the restated year-ago quarter.

AT&T said the robust growth was driven by gains in revenues from consulting, outsourcing and on-line services, including strong subscriber growth at AT&T WorldNet Services. Six months after introduction, AT&T WorldNet is the second largest Internet service provider with 425,000 subscribers.
Overall, quarterly communications services revenue rose $497 million, or four percent, year over year, AT&T said.

Revenue at AT&T's financial services business dropped more than 32 percent to $396 million, primarily because of a securitization program at AT&T Universal Card Services. Some $6.5 billion of Universal Card Services receivables have been securitized. Universal Card expenses for its credit-card rewards program rose from last year's third quarter.
Financial services had an operating loss for the quarter of $35 million, as compared with an operating profit of $47 million in the year-ago quarter.
Customer accounts totaled 18.1 million on September 30.
The demerging company also said total operating expenses from continuing operations increased $530 million, or five percent, for the quarter.

Significant increases in selling, general and administrative expenses were partially offset by a drop in access and other interconnection expenses. Much of the rise came from higher marketing and sales spending in the consumer and wireless businesses, the company said.

Income from discontinued operations such as Lucent Technologies Inc increased to $73 million compared with a significant loss in the year-ago quarter, primarily due to the third quarter 1995 NCR charge.
